title.narrative: Housing, Land And Property Rights’ Challenges Faced In Syria By Refugees Currently Living In Lebanon - Humanitarian Response

description.narrative:
Major HLP issues have been identified as part of the primary assessment conducted in the joint UN-Habitat/UNHCR study on refugees from Homs City in Lebanon, including documentation issues, inheritance issues, damage and destruction of records and physical assets, HLP challenges specific to women-headed households, among many other issues. The study also highlighted the importance of contextualizing the identified HLP issues to derive responsive solutions. The context pertains to the legislative, administrative and urban planning frameworks that govern and shape land/property tenure systems and HLP rights, in different urban and rural areas. HLP issues are critical for multiple humanitarian actors and are central for planning urban recovery in the short and long term while adopting a “do no harm” approach. Therefore, there is a need for an additional in-depth processing and analysis of the identified HLP issues, with the aim to determine the available options for protecting HLP rights of refugees and the needed options for advocacy and programming.
The study identified that safety and security, access to livelihoods, services and housing in Syria are key factors for considering repatriation. The study found that 67.5 percent of Homs refugee households currently did not have ownership documents to their primary property in Syria, with nearly 70 percent being owners of their property in Homs. The study brought to light gender-related issues as well, where 30 percent of surveyed Homs female headed households were widowed and 45 percent had a missing husband, with an anticipated difficulty and complexity in initiating inheritance or restitution of their properties. The study looked at push-pull dynamics, focusing on the perspective of refugees (HLP status in Lebanon, and conditions in areas of origin through the unpublished study), and the implications of the different return scenarios.
The “Two-Year HLP Framework for Syria” highlights priority interventions in the short, medium and long terms across five thematic pillars: legal framework, HLP documentation and land administration, HLP dispute resolution and social cohesion, housing and urban planning, and rural land management. The proposed research project will provide knowledge and information that will directly contribute to the work done under at least two of the five pillars as follows: for the first pillar, the research will categorize the types of HLP claims and link them to the relevant legal framework that can address them, to be translated into actionable options, thus guiding refugees to manage and protect their HLP rights within the realm of Syrian legal systems/institutions. It would also allow exploring options that refugees have during their displacement (outside of Syria) beyond safeguarding their available documents (especially given that a very small percentage of refugees holds documentation of their HLP back in Syria), for better humanitarian response in host countries. The research and more importantly the application will raise the HLP awareness of Syrians allowing them to identify dispute resolution forums that they can access.
The research will help identifying the challenges encountered by displaced Syrian in accessing HLP documentation, including cadastral evidence, and provide recommendations on how HLP documentation can be protected, retrieved or reconstructed. The data analyzed will also help in developing possible scenarios for restitution (individual or large scale) of properties illegally sold or undergoing secondary occupation. The scenarios to be developed will take into account relevant existing legal frameworks and look at what additional measures will be required for such process ( e.g. legal amendments, simplified bureaucratic procedures, institutional capacity building, cost estimation, time estimation, etc.).This research component is crucial for the larger goal of increasing awareness among refugees on their HLP rights as they assess whether to go back to Syria and providing actionable options according to the different HLP challenges. The research team will support the process of developing the building blocks of the digital platform and will provide its users with answers/instructions on “what to do”, by allowing for a categorization of HLP issues, identification of options/actions and outlining due process by case (for example: a household who lost its civil and/or HLP documentation; a household who was a former resident of an informal settlement; a female-headed household who hasn’t initiated an inheritance process; a female-headed household with a missing—not deceased—husband; etc.) according to existing laws. It is important to note that the research and app development processes will proceed in parallel and feed information into each other. Further, the research component will better inform programmatic and advocacy needs that need to be integrated in humanitarian and development responses, in the coming years as the protracted crisis evolves.
